{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3735162,"name":"Rod","username":"Weldingrod1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-09T20:35:55.332Z","cooked":"

I’m going to post some progress on our off-season outreach robot turret, just in case anyone else wants to follow!

A KEY item: I’ve got a couple of nice options for getting wires onto the rotating part!

An important challenge on a turret is how to get power to the rotating part. In some situations you can use an actual full-rotation collector, but ones that will work with a data line AND power aren’t easy to get. Windmill collectors with three phase lines aren’t super expensive, if you can get down to -just- a DC motor on the rotating part.

With careful setup you can have a cable arch where the (spiralled and reinforced) cables point straight up, arch over, and go straight down into the rotating part. Ideally on the center line. With this you can get a part of a turn as the twist in the bundle goes up and down. Kind of easy to booger up, though.

I discovered that Igus has a line of plastic rotary cable chain assemblies! The biggest actually has a pretty good hole in it!
EN_ECS_PROD_PRM Product range_12-2021-PRINT.pdf

image392×275 56 KB

Important tip: the cable chain you see there is special! Normal ones work between straight and a pretty tight curl. THESE go between a large radius backward and a small radius forward. If you are sufficiently crazy, you can set up a milling machine (or some flush cutters) and MAKE this special chain:

image325×230 23 KB

Here’s a comparison of the stock and modified:

image306×186 27.5 KB

You can download the Igus CAD model
Its kind of a big print…
I re-drew things and tuned it up to use an 8” aluminum lazy susan/turntable bearing.

image407×288 39.3 KB

The outer print is messed up (my profile somehow changed from 255C extrusion temperature to 220C. Argh.
I also made some improvements to the attachments. Looks very promising!
Files included if you want to play!

igus_turret_inner_modaa.zip (91.6 KB)

9-19-2025","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":18}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46443,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/5892-off-season-turret/506138/1","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":18}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":18,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3740566,"name":"Rod","username":"Weldingrod1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-16T16:07:16.187Z","cooked":"

The kids have got the cable chain assembly bolted onto the outreach bot. Sorry, didn’t get a picture!
We are discussing shooters…
Here’s a out of the box concept for rotating the turret. With a worm gear, 120 RPM on a 100 tooth gear, 4 starts is 3,000 RPM on the motor, which isn’t completely insane. May still be too fast for a worm. We’ll have to see. It has the big advantage of not needing to go through the bottom plate (no space down there) or sticking up into the shooter space. Probably less backlash than a gearbox plus right angle drive. Obviously NOT back driveable

image719×563 70.5 KB

The actual test gear on our three year old “first try at a turret” gear. Still needs tweaking, plus removing that hub.

image540×720 41.9 KB

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2025-09-16T16:07:16.187Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":517,"readers_count":516,"score":188.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":506138,"topic_slug":"5892-off-season-turret","display_username":"Rod","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46443,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/5892-off-season-turret/506138/2","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3740588,"name":"Tom Line","username":"Tom_Line","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_line/{size}/236809_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-16T16:45:02.715Z","cooked":"

The problem I see there is that you’re applying an axial load to the motor shaft. They may be able to support it, but I doubt they are designed for it. Since a turret is usually pretty well balanced, you may get away with it.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2025-09-16T16:45:02.715Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":477,"readers_count":476,"score":125.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":506138,"topic_slug":"5892-off-season-turret","display_username":"Tom Line","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":46443,"username":"Weldingrod1","name":"Rod","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7841,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team 1498"},"post_url":"/t/5892-off-season-turret/506138/3","custom_user_title":"Team 1498","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3740591,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-16T16:47:42.788Z","cooked":"
Weldingrod1:

May still be too fast for a worm

Setting aside the loading on the motor shaft (axial and radial), is the 3D printed worm going to survive those surface speeds? This isn’t exactly a part that can be in an oil bath…

The moment the worm skips something is going to get mangled. I like the concept in general, it is clever, but it may be a bridge too far at the moment.

The rational behind the large diameter worm is to reasonably mesh with the straight cut spur that is the worm wheel, yes?

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2025-09-16T16:51:35.531Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":478,"readers_count":477,"score":150.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":506138,"topic_slug":"5892-off-season-turret","display_username":"Skye Leake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":19235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Pretengineer"},"post_url":"/t/5892-off-season-turret/506138/4","custom_user_title":"Pretengineer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3740740,"name":"Rod","username":"Weldingrod1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-16T20:32:37.677Z","cooked":"

The large diameter worm was a concept to clear the motor diameter. I think the large diameter worm might be a better mate to a straight spur gear than a small one. Hmmm. A much longer shaft and a smaller worm is almost certainly a better choice. Plus, easier to machine a full-metal one. Easier to get some extra bearings in too. I kinda liked the super-simple “just whack it on the motor shaft” aspect But the big one is delightfully wacky!

I don’t think the axial loads will be too scary on a turret, but its a valid concern! They are often quite large in worm gear systems, especially winches!

Yeah, durability and lubrication will be a problem. A little grease is really all I can offer it. That gear is definitely NOT the right choice; both too big and way too rough. Next test model will be a 3DP part with actual spiral angle on the teeth.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2025-09-16T20:32:37.677Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":447,"readers_count":446,"score":184.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":506138,"topic_slug":"5892-off-season-turret","display_username":"Rod","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":19235,"username":"Skyehawk","name":"Skye Leake","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46443,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/5892-off-season-turret/506138/5","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3744315,"name":"Rod","username":"Weldingrod1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-21T19:08:08.934Z","cooked":"

So, for fun factor, 100:4 starts is mostly back-drivable with glass filled nylon on PETG.
100:5 is -definitely- back driveable!

Here’s the modified cable chain in the guide:

In this vein, I’m also making a trainer for the programmers. 4” turntable bearing, Minion drive, Hall effect 360 pot on the rotation, drive-over limit switch and an IR reflective sensor. They will be able to zoom it around and program response without breaking stuff
I can publish CAD if there’s interest. $250-ish.
Minion $80
Talon $120
Bearing $7 Amazon.com - Cionyce 1 Pack 4 Inch Aluminium Alloy Turntable Bearing Lazy Susan Bearing Swivel Turntable for Table with Rotating Ring(4 Inch)
Hall Pot $30 Amazon.com: Oubit 12-Bit Hall Angle Sensor, 0.088° Resolution, 360° Full Range, 0-5V Analog Output - High-Precision Rotatable Hall Effect Position Sensor : Industrial & Scientific
Thread inserts, screws…
Limit switch (cheap)
IR reflective sensor $9 for 10, HiLetgo 10pcs TCRT5000 Infrared Reflective Sensor

image329×237 27.8 KB

image340×251 29.2 KB

image338×236 37.4 KB

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2025-09-21T21:04:56.249Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":405,"readers_count":404,"score":131.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":506138,"topic_slug":"5892-off-season-turret","display_username":"Rod","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.amazon.com/dp/B0CCP38S7Y","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Amazon.com - Cionyce 1 Pack 4 Inch Aluminium Alloy Turntable Bearing Lazy Susan Bearing Swivel Turntable for Table with Rotating Ring(4 Inch)","clicks":6},{"url":"https://www.amazon.com/dp/B08TTJTWLJ","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Amazon.com: Oubit 12-Bit Hall Angle Sensor, 0.088° Resolution, 360° Full Range, 0-5V Analog Output - High-Precision Rotatable Hall Effect Position Sensor : Industrial & Scientific","clicks":4}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46443,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/5892-off-season-turret/506138/7","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3744393,"name":"Ethan Reed","username":"Ethan_Reed","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ethan_reed/{size}/179877_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-21T21:37:33.543Z","cooked":"

The energy chain concept looks cool. We did similar on 118’s 2024 robot. We found issues with kinking and binding, so we added a guiding pulley using a planetary gear to synchronize the motion of the loop and keep the chain tight on the ID. We also just used standard reverse bend radius energy chain from WCP. The gear pitch was modeled to match the pitch of the chain.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2025-09-21T21:37:33.543Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":8,"reads":384,"readers_count":383,"score":391.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":506138,"topic_slug":"5892-off-season-turret","display_username":"Ethan Reed","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XhEuGWrkQzY","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":5}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":46443,"username":"Weldingrod1","name":"Rod","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":18}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":31183,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"118 Drive Coach & Everybot"},"post_url":"/t/5892-off-season-turret/506138/8","custom_user_title":"118 Drive Coach & Everybot","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":18}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":18,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3744743,"name":"Rod","username":"Weldingrod1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-22T02:01:35.250Z","cooked":"

That’s a cool creation!
I found that the arc shaped fixed guide for the inner edge of the chain was quite important; I did a test without it and it really didn’t work well… One of the early photos shows that guide quite a bit farther from the chain, which was also bad.
My chain is modified to have a fixed reverse bending radius that is quite close to the inner guide tube radius.

We’ll have to spin it fast with the Kraken tester tomorrow and see what happens!

This sounds like a great initiative! I’m also learning how to design a turret right now. Would it be possible to add a link to the file? It would really help me understand how to CAD one

Is that motor mount going to be strong enough to hold the motor? It looks fairly thin and has a weak spot along the layer lines

Layer bonding is always a challenge with 3DP parts! And an important reason for adding the bearing on the far end. Its not a competition robot, but then it IS an outreach robot… I don’t know which is worse

The current worm seems to have broached off-axis, so things wriggle around as I rotate the worm. Making a fresh one… I’ll have to be extra careful broaching this one!

@BUG I can post STEP files, if that’s useful to you. Did you want the big one, the small one, or both?

Got all the bits for the small one printed overnight! The 3rd try at the big ring is getting close, after printing all night.

image117×147 36.3 KB

I’ve gotta say, its crazy talk fast. When you goose it you can’t actually see it move, it just appears in the next position… Full whack is 7,500 RPM down to 375 RPM on the turret. 6 revolutions per second.

I’m kinda wondering if I want to give up the backdriveability and make it slower…

Weldingrod1:

give up the backdriveability

Maybe there is a simple answer I’m missing, but why would backdriveability be a desired feature for a turret?

","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2025-09-23T20:29:55.555Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":14,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":256,"readers_count":255,"score":71.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":506138,"topic_slug":"5892-off-season-turret","display_username":"Karl Olson","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":36434,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Technical Mentor | 3476"},"post_url":"/t/5892-off-season-turret/506138/15","custom_user_title":"Technical Mentor | 3476","reactions":[{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"thinking","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3746309,"name":"","username":"elin-semicolon-D","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/e/e36b37/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-09-23T20:50:04.084Z","cooked":"

here’s my train of thought: Anything that isn’t backdriving is going to make the turret “stall“ at its current position. So lets say if there is a big impact force that is going to ram into whatever’s mounted onto the turret, the energy has to go somewhere. If the thing is stalled, the nergy is probably going into the deformation of the turret, worm gear, the individual joints that mounted the mechanism on to the turret, or the mechanism itself.

Get a spider style Lovejoy coupling or similar to eat some of those shock loads if it is kept backdrivble and better support the loads the worm imposes, should be able to fine tune it with TPU.

"Give a little" - keeping mechanisms from exploding on impact Technical
Just some quick and dirty CAD that would probably need a little work. Idea is to be able to drive a mechanism (intake) forward, but when hit (i.e. run into feeder station wall ) there is some give in the reverse direction before the motor. Keeps things from exploding. This is a reduction on a jackshaft. Magenta hub on the gear side is the input ( or the hex shaft, or the gear itself (which can be omitted and replaced with a short piece of maxspline)) is the input - sprocket output. When viewed…

I imagine a turret with high speed characteristics would be cool for things like a 2020 style game but with a pair of goals, one that is “hot”, like 2014

If you’re concerned about axial load (which it doesn’t seem like you are, but just in case) it might be worth it to try and capture the shaft on the other side. A simple 1/2” hex extension on the worm and a corresponding bearing plate would get you there.
